TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Clayey-skeletal, mixed, active Typic Haplocryods

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON: Sherburne gravelly loam - forest. (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise stated.)
0i--0 to 0.25 inch; fresh needles and twigs. A few pebbles ant cobbles are exposed at the surface. (1/4 to 1 inch thick)
0e--0.25 to 0.75 inch; platy, matted, partially decayed organic material. (1/4 to 3/4 inch thick)
E--0.75 inch to 2.25 inches; light gray (10YR 7/2) gravelly loam, grayish brown (10YR 5/2) moist; weak thin platy structure; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky, slightly plastic; many very fine roots; many very fine and micro tubular pores and common fine vesicles and tubular pores; silt, sand and gravel are uncoated; 25 percent subangular pebbles; extremely acid (pH 4.1); abrupt smooth boundary. (1 to 2 inches thick)
Bs1--2.25 to 11 inches; light yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) gravelly loam, brown (7.5YR 4/4) moist; moderate very fine granular structure; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky, slightly plastic; many very fine roots, mostly horizontal, and few fine roots; many very fine and few fine tubular pores; silt, sand and gravel stained and pebbles coated with silt; 30 percent gravel; very strongly acid (pH 5.0); clear wavy boundary. (5 to 10 inches thick)
Bs2--11 to 19 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/3) gravelly loam, dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist; weak fine subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky, slightly plastic; common very fine and few fine roots; many very fine and few fine tubular pores; silt, sand and gravel stained and gravel coated with silt; 30 percent gravel; strongly acid (pH 5.1); clear wavy boundary. (0 to 11 inches thick)
2Bt1--19 to 47 inches; light yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) very gravelly clay loam, brown (7.5YR 4/4) moist; moderate fine subangular blocky structure; hard, firm, sticky and plastic; common very fine and few fine roots; many very fine and few fine tubular pores; clay bridging sand and patches of clay films on pebbles and walls of pebble sockets; silt and sand grains are stained; 40 percent gravel; very strongly acid (pH 4.7); clear wavy boundary.
2Bt2--47 to 91 inches; reddish yellow (7.5YR 6/6) very cobbly clay, yellowish red (5YR 4/6) moist; moderate thick platy structure that parts to moderate fine blocks; extremely hard, very firm, sticky, plastic; few roots; many very fine tubular and common fine interstitial pores; thick patches of clay film on pebbles and bridging sand grains; patches of unstained sand; 30 percent cobbles and 20 percent gravel; very strongly acid (pH 5.0); clear wavy boundary.
3C--91 to 101 inches; light yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) clay, brown (7.5YR 5/4) moist; massive; extremely hard, friable, sticky, plastic; 10 percent gravel; slightly acid (pH 6.3)

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION: Glacier County, Montana; 1.9 miles north on Hilton Sawmill road off U. S. Highway 89 at milepost 440; NW1/4 of section 11, T.34N., R.14W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS: Solum thickness ranges from 5 to 8 feet. Mean annual soil temperature ranges from 37 to 39 degrees F., average summer soil temperature ranges from 42 to 45 degrees F. and average winter soil temperature from 30 to 33 degrees F. The soil is usually moist but is generally dry between 10 and 30 inches for about 30 days in late July and early August, becoming moist again in the fall.
The Bs1 horizon has hue of 7.5YR, value of 5 or 6 dry and 4 moist and chroma of 3 or 4 dry and 3 through 6 moist. The Bs2 horizon has hue of 10YR or 7.5YR, value of 5 or 6 dry and 4 moist and chroma of 3 or 4 dry and 3 through 6 moist. Rock fragments average from 20 to 35 percent by volume and are mainly less than 3 inches in diameter. A few cobbles and stones occur in most pedons.
The 2Bt horizon has hue of 10YR to 5YR, value of 6 or 7 dry and 4 or 5 moist and chroma of 2 through 6. It ranges from very gravelly clay loam to extremely cobbly clay with clay content increasing with increased depth. The upper two feet of the horizon has 35 to 45 percent clay. Rock fragments range from 40 to 70 percent and consist of pebbles, cobbles and stones up to 20 inches in diameter.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES: There are no other soils in this family.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING: Sherburne soils are on nearly level to sloping remnants of old high level plains bordering the eastern slopes of the northern Rocky Mountains. They occur between 5,500 and 6,500 feet above sea level. Winters in the area are long and cold but are frequently interrupted by warm Chinook winds. Summers are short and relatively warm. Precipitation ranges from 20 to 35 inches with approximately 200 inches of winter snow. Parent material of the Sherburne series is very old glacial till or glacial outwash from mixed argillite, quartzite, limestone, and basic intrusive rock sources. Most of these materials are high in iron minerals. Volcanic ash makes up only 3 percent of the coarse silt fraction (20 to 50 microns) of the E horizon, and a trace below at the type location.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS: These are the Babb, Croffs, Letarg, Loberg and Tenex soils. Babb soils have mollic epipedons but lack clay accumulation in the B horizon. Tenex soils lack an argillic horizon. Croffs soils occur on smooth land forms similar to the Sherburne but are under grass and have a dark colored A1 horizon. Letarg and Loberg soils occur at lower elevations than the Sherburne soils on younger glacial till.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY: Well-drained; medium runoff; moderately slow to slow permeability. This, accompanied with frozen soils and rapid snowmelt in June, results in a perched water table for a short period in some years.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION: The major use is forest with very limited grazing. Timber stands range from 25- to 35-year old lodgepole pine to mixed, overmature stands of lodgepole pine, alpine fir and Englemann spruce.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT: Sherburne soils are inextensive, occurring on the eastern slopes of the Rocky Mountains in Montana.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED: Glacier County (Blackfeet Reservation-Cut Bank Area), Montana, 1969.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS: REMARKS: Diagnostic horizons and feature recognized in this pedon are:
Ochric epipedon, the zone from 3/4 to 1 1/4 inches; (E horizons)
Albic horizon, the zone from 3/4 to 1 1/4 inches; (E horizons)
Spodic horizon, the zone from 1 1/4 to 11 inches; (Bs1 horizon)
Argillic horizon, the zone from 19 to 91 inches; (Bt horizon)
Particle-size control section 11 to 41 inches
This draft reflects a change in classification from Clayey-skeletal, mixed Boralfic Cryorthods to Clayey-skeletal, mixed, active Typic Haplocryods
